review.title: Soft Neutrosophic Algebraic Structures and Their Generalization
review.abstract: Study of soft sets was first proposed by Molodtsov in 1999 to deal with uncertainty in a non-parametric manner. The researchers did not pay attention to soft set theory at that time but now the soft set theory has been developed in many areas of mathematics. Algebraic structures using soft set theory are very rapidly developed. In this book we developed soft neutrosophic algebraic structures by using soft sets and neutrosophic algebraic structures. In this book we study soft neutrosophic groups, soft neutrosophic semigroups, soft neutrosophic loops, soft neutrosophic LA-semigroups, and their generalizations respectively.

sections.heading: Chapter Six
sections.text: This book is dedicated to my beloved Farzana Ahmad. Her kind support and love always encourage me to work on this work. Whenever I am excited and alone, her guidance gives me a better chance to do something better. I am deeply grateful to her and dedicate this book to her. This is my humble way of paying homage to her support, kindness and love.

sections.heading: PREFACE
sections.text: In this book, the authors presented the concepts of soft neutrosophicalgebraic structures, which are defined by the Neutrosophical Algebraic Structures, i.e. a parametrized collection of subgroups of the Neutrosophicalgebraic Structure. For example, the existence of a soft neutrosophical group via a Neutrosophical Algebraic Group, or a soft neutrosophical semigroup via a Neutrosophicalgebraic Semigroup, or a soft neutrosophical field via a Neutrosophical Field, or a soft neutrosophical LA Semigroup via a Neutrosophical LA Semigroup, or a soft Neutrosophical Semigroup. Interestingly, these concepts are defined by finite and infiniteneutrosophical Algebraic Structures, which are even larger than the classical Neutrosophical Neutrosophical Neutrosophical Semigroup.

sections.heading: INTRODUCTION
sections.text: In this chapter we give some basic concepts and terms. This chapter has 5 sections. The first section contains the terms of Neutrosophical Groups, Neutrosophical Big Groups and Neutrosophical N-Groups. In Section 2 we mentioned Neutrosophical Semi-Groups, Neutrosophical Bisemigroups and Neutrosophical N-Half Groups. Section 3 deals with Neutrosophile Bi-LA Semi-Groups and their generalizations. In Section 4 we give some introductory descriptions of Neutrosophical Left Almost Semigroup Derived Asneutrosophical LA Semigroups, Neutrosophical Bi-LA Semigroups and Neutrosophical N-LA Semi-Groups and their related properties. In the last section we have given some basic literature on the theory of soft set groups and their related properties that will contribute to understanding the theory of soft set groups.

sections.text: This chapter consists of three sections. In the first section, we present their important notions of soft neutrosophical groups over neutrrosophical groups, which are actually a collection of parametrized families of neutrosophical subgroups, and we also give some of their characterization with enough examples in this section. In the second section, we talk about soft neutrosophical big groups, which are essentially defined as super-neutrrosophical big groups. In this section, we also note some basic results of soft neutrosophical big groups. In the third section, we talk about the generalization of soft neutrosophical big groups. In this section, we have defined soft neutrosophicN groups over neutrrosophical N groups, and some of their basic properties are also examined.

sections.heading: GENERALIZATION
sections.text: In this chapter, the term soft neutrosophical semigroup and its generalization is given. This chapter comprises three sections. In the first section, the soft neutrosophical semigroup is introduced via a neutrosophical semigroup. In fact, soft neutrosophical semigroups are a parametrized collection of neutrosophical subsemigroups. We also examine the soft neutrosophical strong semigroup via a neutrosophical semigroup based purely on neutrosophical behavior. Now, to define the soft neutrosophical semigroup via a neutrosophical semigroup, we proceed as follows:

sections.text: This chapter comprises three sections. In the first section, we present the important notions of soft, neutrrosophic LA half-groups, which are non-neutrrosophic LA half-groups, which are actually a collection of parameterized families of neutrrosophic sub-LA half-groups, and we also examine some of their characterization using sufficient examples in this section. The second section deals with soft Neutrosophicbi-LA half-groups, which are essentially defined by neutrrosophic Bi-LA half-groups. In this section, we also establish some basic results of soft, neutrrosophic Bi-LA half-groups. The third section deals with the generalization of soft, neutrrosophic LA half-groups. In this section, we define soft, neutrrosophic N-LA half-groups by neutrrosophic N-LA half-groups, and some of their basic properties are also examined.

sections.heading: Soft Neutrosophic Storng Bi-LA-semigroup
sections.text: The term soft neutrosophile strong bi-LA semigroup over a neutrosophile bi-LA semigroup is introduced here. We gave the definition of soft neutrosophile strong bi-LA semigroup and examined some related properties with sufficient quantity of illustrative examples. Definition 5.2.5: Let () BN S be a neutrosophile strong subbi-LA semigroup, if and only if () F a is a neutrosophile bi-LA semigroup, is a neutrrosophile bi-semigroup, if () F a is a neutrrosophile strong subbi-LA semigroup and (,) F-semisoft group for all. Example 5.2.5: Let () BN S be a neutrosophile bi-semigroup in Example 5.1.1. Let 1 {,} A a strong set of parameters. Then () F A is a soft neutrosophile strong, strong bi-LA semigroup.

sections.heading: 5.3 Soft Neutrosophic N-LA-semigroup
sections.text: In this section we expand soft sets to neutrosophilic N-LA semigroups and introduce soft neutrosophilic N-LA semigroups. This is the generalization of soft neutrosophilic LA semigroups. Some of their impotent facts and figures are also presented here with illustrative examples. We also initiated the strong part of neutrosophy in this section. Now we move on to the definition of soft neutrosophilic N-LA semigroups as follows. Definition 5.3.1: Let 1 2 (),...,} NS N be a neutrosophilic N-LA semigroup (,) {} 1soft Isoft group (F A be a soft set over () S N n. Then (,) F A is called soft neutrosophicN-LA semigroup if and only if () F a is a neutrosophilic group among N-LA semigroups.

sections.heading: Soft Neutrosophic Strong N-LA-semigroup
sections.text: The terms of the soft neutrosophic strong N-LA semigroups over the neutrosophic N-LA semigroups are presented here. We give some basic definitions of the soft neutrosophic strong N-LA semigroups and illustrate it with the help of the exmaphs and give some basic neutral results 5.3.4: Let 1 2 {(),,,..., NS N be a neutrosophic N-LA semigroup and (,) F A be a soft set over () S n. Then (,) F A is called a soft neutrosophic strong N-LA semigroup if () F a is a neutrosophic strong subN-LA semigroup of () S n. sections.heading: Chapter Six
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: SUGGESTED PROBLEMS
sections.text: In this chapter some problems about the soft neutrosophic structures and soft neutrosophic neutrosophic structures of a soft neutrosophic group are given.These problems are as follows: 1. Can one define soft neutrosophic neutrosophic groups via a neutrosophic neutrosophic group? 2. How can one define seminrosophic neutrosophic neutrosophic neutrosophic neutrosophic groups via a neutrosophic neutrosophic neutrosophic group? 4. How can one define soft neutrosophic neutrosophic neutrosophic neutrosophic neutrosophic neutrosophic neutrosophic neutrosophic neutrosophic neutrosophic neutrosophic neutrosophic neutrosophic neutrosophic neutrosophic groups via a neutrosophic neutrosophic neutrosophic neutrosophic neutrosophic group? 4.

sections.heading: ABOUT THE AUTHORS
sections.text: Dr. Florentin Smarandache is Professor of Mathematics at the University of New Mexico in the USA. He has published over 75 books and 100 articles and notes in the fields of mathematics, physics, philosophy, psychology, literature, Rebus. In mathematics, he researches in the fields of number theory, non-Euclidean geometry, synthetic geometry, algebraic structures, statistics, neutrosophical logic and set theory (generalizations of fuzzy logic and set theory), neutrosophical probability (generalization of classical and imprecise probabilities), small contributions to nuclear and particle physics, information fusion, neutrosophy (a generalization of dialectics), law of sensations and stimuli, etc. He can be contacted at smarand @ unm.eduMumtaz Ali.
